thread.title: Bozeman clinches postseason berth with rout of Bison
thread.title_full: Bozeman clinches postseason berth with rout of Bison

author: Parker Gabriel Chronicle Sports Writer
title: Bozeman clinches postseason berth with rout of Bison
text:
Comments 
If the Hawks had any concerns about a dip in performance following last week’s wild, 20-19 win over Billings Senior, they were erased quickly — and emphatically — against Great Falls High in the Electric City on Friday. 
Bozeman scored on its first drive, rolled up 28 points in the second quarter, and blew out the Bison, 42-7. 
“Any time you’re on a bus trip following a big game, you worry about it,” Hawks head coach Troy Purcell said of the 185-mile journey north. “I’m real impressed with the kids treating it as a business trip and being ready to go right from the start.” 
With the win, the Hawks (7-1) locked up a playoff spot and remained in the driver’s seat for the No. 1 seed in Class AA, which would mean home-field advantage throughout the postseason. 
“Any time you can play at home, I love playing in our stadium, and if we can pull this off and get a couple more wins, it’s going to be a fun place to play,” Purcell said, adding the school has only hosted nine playoff games. 
Despite a dominant rushing attack, Bozeman’s first three scores came in other ways. Senior quarterback DJ Perdaems hit Bennett Hostetler for a 25-yard score midway through the first quarter, then Cade Wessel for 20 and a touchdown early in the second. 
The Hawks extended the lead when Great Falls threw the ball on fourth and 2, but quarterback Kaden Sukut had his pass deflected by Wessel and intercepted by Brock Behan, who returned it 55 yards for a touchdown and a 21-0 lead. 
“(The defense was) sound all around,” Purcell said. “The kids played really well and then our No. 2s got scored on at the end of the game, that kind of deal.” 
The backups got plenty of work on this night. 
Perdaems scored finished off Bozeman’s first drive of the second half with a 3-yard touchdown run with 8 minutes, 20 seconds remaining in the period, ending a short but efficient evening of work for the starters on both sides of the ball. 
That didn’t keep the Hawks from rolling up some gaudy numbers on the ground. Senior Trace Bradshaw finished with 140 yards on just eight carries, including a 76-yard rumble that set up a score in the first half’s waning moments. Balue Chapman finished with 88 total yards (41 rushing), including a 28-yard touchdown reception from Perdaems. Junior back Austin Hoell handled the workload late, gaining 36 on 11 carries. 
All told, Bozeman ran for 260 yards, held the Bison to 59 and posted a 390-186 advantage in total offense. The Hawks didn’t punt until the closing minutes of the third quarter. 
The visitors did commit 12 penalties, but otherwise dominated across the board. 
“The coaching’s doing a great job,” Purcell said. “If things are working real smooth, that means there’s just a good combination of people working together.” 
The Hawks play their final two regular season games at Van Winkle Stadium, and would ensure they don’t make another road trip this season with wins over Great Falls CMR and Billings Skyview. 
“You look past anybody in high school football and you could be on the outside looking in,” Purcell said. “We just have to take care of business each week.” 
Still, he admitted his team has put itself in great position, and at this late point in the season it’s not worth denying that the No. 1 seed is there for the taking. 
“Any loss on the way and you’re sacrificing home field advantage throughout,” he said. “It’s out in the future, but it’s definitely a realistic goal that we can accomplish.”
